channel.title: Any good Javascript tutorial websites?
channel.description: Been looking around, and I really don't like much of whats out there(lots of the sites are outdated and use terrible syntax <HTML><SCRIPT>)

item.title: Any good Javascript tutorial websites?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“nickb, post:12, topic:517670”]Maybe you could try this: http://blog.themeforest.net/screencasts/jquery-for-absolute-beginners-video-series/
JQuery is a library from Javascript. And yeah in my opinion, JQuery is easier to learn then Javascript.[/quote]You should learn how to use the language before you learn how to use a library.

Read full topic

[/quote]

Everything you need to know about W3Schools can be found here: W3 Fools[/quote]

Lol, ok, I’ll stay away from there then

item.title: Any good Javascript tutorial websites?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Flame_, post:2, topic:517670”][ul][li]http://www.w3schools.com/js/[/li]
[li]http://www.codeproject.com/Articles/755/JavaScript-For-Beginners[/li]
[li]https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/JavaScript[/li][/ul]

Not sure on the validity or reputation of each site, but that’s what I’ve pulled up after a bit of looking, and they seem fairly trustworthy from what I see.[/quote]The only one s out of that list that I would recommend is Mozilla’s. I would stay away from w3schools completely.

[quote=“justaguy, post:3, topic:517670”]http://eloquentjavascript.net/

Is pretty good.[/quote]This.

[quote=“tigerclan, post:6, topic:517670”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=635932.msg4287378#msg4287378 date=1366591955]

hmmm, thanks for the quick response guys. tbh I thought the transition from Java to JavaScript would be a lot harder. Everyone always told me they were way different but it’s written pretty much the same, with some minute changes/different methods/etc

I’m not sure how far in you’ve gone with Javascript but they are pretty different.
[/quote]

perhaps not enough, but im just referring to the same basic syntax

void writeOutput() {
    System.out.println("Some output");
}
function writeOutput() {
    document.write("Some output");
}

Seems to me at least the basic parts are close. Just starting to read on jQuery though, which is obviously a lot different lol[/quote]Don’t use document.write.

This function tries to write to the current document. If the document has already been processed, the document will be replaced with a blank one with your argument. If you don’t want that, use the proper DOM methods instead.

jQuery is just a Javascript library. There’s nothing special about it, it doesn’t have special syntax.

Read full topic

item.title: Any good Javascript tutorial websites?
item.dc:creator: @RevengePK RevengePK
item.description:
@RevengePK wrote:

I download premade javascripts, jQuery plugins, etc and look at the structure of the code and do research on each part I do not understand. I’m terrible with tutorials because I have the attention span of a peanut.

Read full topic

item.title: Any good Javascript tutorial websites?
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

[quote=“justaguy, post:5, topic:517670”][quote author=tigerclan link=topic=635932.msg4287368#msg4287368 date=1366590297]
hmmm, thanks for the quick response guys. tbh I thought the transition from Java to JavaScript would be a lot harder. Everyone always told me they were way different but it’s written pretty much the same, with some minute changes/different methods/etc
[/quote]

I’m not sure how far in you’ve gone with Javascript but they are pretty different.[/quote]

perhaps not enough, but im just referring to the same basic syntax

void writeOutput() {
    System.out.println("Some output");
}
function writeOutput() {
    document.write("Some output");
}

Seems to me at least the basic parts are close. Just starting to read on jQuery though, which is obviously a lot different lol

Read full topic
